title.narrative: Mosul Emergency Response SGBV and CP Prevention and Response in As Salamyiah Camp

description.narrative:
Exacerbated by the recent military operation to retake territory including Mosul from ISIS, the political and humanitarian context in Iraq continues to be subjected to unpredictable deterioration of security driven by sectarian conflict, thus continuing to deteriorate the economy and humanitarian context and creating an unprecedented level of protracted displacement. As many as 11 million are expected to require some form of humanitarian support in 2017 included in this figure is 750,000 facing life-threatening protection risks in Western Mosul. One of the most devastating impacts of the humanitarian crisis has been on women and children and on an entire generation of adolescent girls and boys. The 2016 Humanitarian Needs Overview for Iraq identified Gender-based violence, in particular sexual violence, is as a prevalent aspect of both the conflict and displacement across Iraq. ISIL has used sexual violence systematically, targeting women and girls of specific ethnic and religious communities, committing killings, torture, rape, sexual slavery and trafficking that may amount to war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide. The 2016 HNO identified the need for urgent support to mitigate against the risk of potentially fueling violence for decades to come, and the need to provide a foundation for future social stability.
Women Rehabilitation Organization aims to implement “Mosul Emergency SGBV and CP Prevention and Response in As Salamyiah Camp Project” in order to meet the lifesaving needs of Women, Girls, Men, and Boy sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) survivors, the most vulnerable at risk of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), and Children Protection (CP) through increase awareness raising, emergency psychosocial support, case management, unaccompanied and separated children (UASC) identification and documentation, and non-formal psychosocial recreational activities. This project will provide immediate protection and mental health/psychosocial support (MH/PSS) remedies to internationally displaced persons (IDPs) fleeing Mosul through a static and mobile response. WRO will provide the aforementioned emergency services activities for the immediate and future benefit of women and girls and boys and men. Objective: Meet the immediate life saving Child Protection/Gender Based Violence (CP/ GBV) protection needs of the most vulnerable through integrated mobilization service provision
Through 1 static center and 1 outreach team Women Rehabilitation Organization will provide the following sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) and child protection (CP) Joint Prevention and Response Activities:  Conduct service mapping and develop child protection and gender-based violence referral pathways  Provide gender-based violence and child protection case management for survivors and those most at risk and referral to specialized services  Provide gender-based violence and child protection psychological first aid (PFA) and psychosocial support, including for adolescent girls, female headed households, disabled.  Identify and document unaccompanied and separated children (UASC)  Provide psychological first Aid to children and their families  Provide structured psychosocial support non-formal recreational activities to children and caregivers  Conduct awareness raising activities on child protection and gender-based violence issues though house to house visits, mass information dissemination and awareness raising sessions in the center, and engaging community leaderscore concepts trainings for camp management, non child protection/gender-based violence actors.  Raise awareness on survivor rights, safety and available services  Conduct site-, local- and higher-level Advocacy  Conduct gender-based violence and child protection Safety Audits.
